channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HADOOP-13073] RawLocalFileSystem does not react on changing umask
item.description:
FileSystemContractBaseTest#testMkdirsWithUmask is changing umask under the filesystem. RawLocalFileSystem reads the config on startup so it will not react if we change the umask.
It blocks HADOOP-7363 since testMkdirsWithUmask test will never work with RawLocalFileSystem.
item.summary: RawLocalFileSystem does not react on changing umask

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: you'll need to make the test choose its umask policy based on OS, unless the windows native stuff is present it will fail there.
I planned to put my tests into TestLocalFileSystemPermission class. This class does not run tests on Windows so I planned to skip as well. What do you think?

stevel@apache.org mattf arpitagarwal
Could you please review my patch?

stevel@apache.org, mattf, arpitagarwal, cnauroth,

Could you please review this one? It blocks me to finish HADOOP-7363. Thanks in advance.

This message was automatically generated.
Test failure is unrelated.

Note for the patch:
I had to modify testLocalFSDirsetPermission as well because it runs after my new test. My test sets FS_PERMISSIONS_UMASK_KEY to 022.
testLocalFSDirsetPermission tries to use 044. The old code creates a new Configuration and set the umask to 044 then gets the localfs with that config. But in fact under the hood the new Configuration object will be thrown and we get the localfs from cache (with umask 022).
When we get filesystem from cache we use the config object as key but actually the config object is not used in Key's constructor. Please check Key(URI uri, Configuration conf, long unique) throws IOException { method in FileSystem.java.
That is why I had to modify that testcase too.
This is very misleading and it is easy to use FileSystem.getLocal on the wrong way (just like in this test class).

I'd just committed this to trunk, then noticed the System.out() calls in the test case and reverted the test, sorry.

-1

Could you create a logger for the class and use that for printing messages. Ideally, moving the existing System.out changes in there.

Note that the patch would only work against trunk, not branch-2. I'm happy with that.

I used System.out because it was still used and I kept my patch as small as possible.
Reattaching last patch to kick hadoopqa.
